user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskSetPriority_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskSetPriority_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, osal_priority_t new_priority)
{
    int os_priority;
    int ret;

    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    if (POSIX_GlobalVars.EnableTaskPriorities)
    {
        /* Change OSAL priority into a priority that will work for this OS */
        os_priority = OS_PriorityRemap(new_priority);

        /*
        ** Set priority
        */
        ret = pthread_setschedprio(impl->id, os_priority);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("pthread_setschedprio: Task ID = %lu, prio = %d, err = %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), os_priority, strerror(ret));
            return OS_ERROR;
        }
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskSetPriority_Impl:
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
OS_impl_task_internal_record_t OS_impl_task_table[OS_MAX_TASKS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t id;
} OS_impl_task_internal_record_t
...
static int OS_PriorityRemap(osal_priority_t InputPri)
{
    int OutputPri;

    if (InputPri == 0)
    {
        /* use the "MAX" local priority only for OSAL tasks with priority=0 */
        OutputPri = POSIX_GlobalVars.PriLimits.PriorityMax;
    }
    else if (InputPri >= OS_MAX_TASK_PRIORITY)
    {
        /* use the "MIN" local priority only for OSAL tasks with priority=255 */
        OutputPri = POSIX_GlobalVars.PriLimits.PriorityMin;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Spread the remainder of OSAL priorities over the remainder of local priorities
         *
         * Note OSAL priorities use the VxWorks style with zero being the
         * highest and OS_MAX_TASK_PRIORITY being the lowest, this inverts it
         */
        OutputPri = (OS_MAX_TASK_PRIORITY - 1) - (int)InputPri;

        OutputPri *= (POSIX_GlobalVars.PriLimits.PriorityMax - POSIX_GlobalVars.PriLimits.PriorityMin) - 2;
        OutputPri += OS_MAX_TASK_PRIORITY / 2;
        OutputPri /= (OS_MAX_TASK_PRIORITY - 2);
        OutputPri += POSIX_GlobalVars.PriLimits.PriorityMin + 1;
    }

    return OutputPri;
}
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
OS_DEBUG("pthread_setschedprio: Task ID = %lu, prio = %d, err = %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), os_priority, strerror(ret));
explanation: I scanned the target function and the related definitions provided. No other calls to string.h functions (such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) are present in the shown code. The only expression involving a string-handling facility is the strerror(ret) argument inside the OS_DEBUG invocation shown above. Other functions in the excerpt (OS_PriorityRemap, OS_ObjectIdFromToken, OS_ObjectIdToInteger) do not use string.h functions or pointer-based string operations, and there are no visible buffer copies or pointer arithmetic involving C-string functions elsewhere in the provided snippets. Therefore no additional fragments need investigation beyond the one listed.
